headline.main: Shuttle Crew: Six Veterans And a Rookie

results.snippet: Capt. Daniel C. Brandenstein Mission Commander    Captain Brandenstein, 49 years old, of the Navy has flown three shuttle missions since 1983 and served as commander on the last two.    Before joining NASA in 1978, Captain Brandenstein was a naval...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Daniel C. Brandenstein Mission Commander Captain Brandenstein, 49 years old, of the Navy has flown three shuttle missions since 1983 and served as commander on the last two. Before joining NASA in 1978, Captain Brandenstein was a naval aviator and flew 192 combat missions in Southeast Asia from 1968 to 1970. He is chief of NASA's Astronaut Office.

headline.main: Newest Shuttle, Endeavour, Begins First Mission

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour roared aloft tonight on its inaugural flight, carrying six men and a woman on a rescue mission to save a $150 million communications satellite stranded in space for more than two years.   The 100-ton Endeavour blasted...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour roared aloft tonight on its inaugural flight, carrying six men and a woman on a rescue mission to save a $150 million communications satellite stranded in space for more than two years. The 100-ton Endeavour blasted off at 7:40 P.M., spewing white vapor and orange flame as it thundered through a partly cloudy sky to begin a seven-day flight.

headline.main: Shuttle Fails Twice to Capture Satellite

results.snippet: In a tense drama some 230 miles above Earth, astronauts in spacesuits tried and failed tonight to pluck a wayward satellite from orbit and move it into the payload bay of the space shuttle Endeavour.   The aim was to latch the satellite onto an...
results.lead_paragraph: In a tense drama some 230 miles above Earth, astronauts in spacesuits tried and failed tonight to pluck a wayward satellite from orbit and move it into the payload bay of the space shuttle Endeavour. The aim was to latch the satellite onto an engine that would have hurled the $150 million communications relay into its rightful place high above Earth.

headline.main: Shuttle Again Fails to Capture Stranded Satellite

results.snippet: For the second consecutive day, a wayward satellite tonight eluded capture by the astronauts of the space shuttle Endeavour.    The astronauts repeatedly tried to grab the $150 million communications relay satellite and haul it from the cold void...
results.lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive day, a wayward satellite tonight eluded capture by the astronauts of the space shuttle Endeavour. The astronauts repeatedly tried to grab the $150 million communications relay satellite and haul it from the cold void of space into the payload bay of the shuttle Endeavour.

headline.main: Case of the Adaptable Spy: Agent for Soviets, and Russia, Too

results.snippet: In a 27-year career as a journalist for a leading Belgian newspaper, Guido Kindt developed a reputation as an aerospace expert. So it did not surprise his colleagues when he recently developed a close friendship with Belgium's first astronaut, who...
results.lead_paragraph: In a 27-year career as a journalist for a leading Belgian newspaper, Guido Kindt developed a reputation as an aerospace expert. So it did not surprise his colleagues when he recently developed a close friendship with Belgium's first astronaut, who was aboard the Atlantis shuttle that completed a 10-day flight on April 2. So close was the friendship with the astronaut, a physicist named Dirk Frimout, that Mr. Kindt was the only Belgian journalist invited to a party held for the Atlantis crew in Houston on April 5. Then, on April 7, Mr. Kindt returned from the United States to Brussels, and three days later he was arrested on charges of spying for the former Soviet Union and for Russia.

headline.main: Space Agency Plans to Send Crew of 3 to Grab Wobbling Satellite

results.snippet: After repeated failures to rescue a wayward communications satellite, the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour today proposed a last-ditch plan that calls for space walks by three astronauts on Wednesday. Late tonight the shutttle's ground...
results.lead_paragraph: After repeated failures to rescue a wayward communications satellite, the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour today proposed a last-ditch plan that calls for space walks by three astronauts on Wednesday. Late tonight the shutttle's ground controllers agreed to the astronauts' plan. That many astronauts venturing into space at one time would be a first.

headline.main: 3 Astronauts, in Space Walk, Grab Errant Satellite

results.snippet: Three astronauts ventured into the vacuum of space Wednesday night, reached out with gloved hands and snared a wayward satellite.   It was the first time so many astronauts had gone forth into space together and the first time anyone had captured...
results.lead_paragraph: Three astronauts ventured into the vacuum of space Wednesday night, reached out with gloved hands and snared a wayward satellite. It was the first time so many astronauts had gone forth into space together and the first time anyone had captured an orbiting satellite with nothing but their hands. All previous salvage jobs and previous attempts on this mission had mainly used some type of hardware.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS MAKE A NEW SPACE WALK AFTER RESCUE FEAT

results.snippet: Buoyed by their last-minute triumph in capturing an errant satellite, astronauts of the shuttle Endeavour took a fourth walk in space Thursday, staying out almost eight hours to rehearse constructing NASA's planned 350-foot space station.    And as...
results.lead_paragraph: Buoyed by their last-minute triumph in capturing an errant satellite, astronauts of the shuttle Endeavour took a fourth walk in space Thursday, staying out almost eight hours to rehearse constructing NASA's planned 350-foot space station. And as the satellite they saved on Wednesday blasted toward its correct orbit, aerospace experts praised and debated the high-stakes rescue that featured history's first satellite capture by astronauts using nothing but their gloved hands.

headline.main: Relieved Astronauts Describe Improvising Satellite's Rescue

results.snippet: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour said today that their training, intensive as it was, did not prepare them for the difficult job of capturing a whirling 9,000-pound satellite.   "It's something we couldn't train for," said Comdr....
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour said today that their training, intensive as it was, did not prepare them for the difficult job of capturing a whirling 9,000-pound satellite. "It's something we couldn't train for," said Comdr. Pierre J. Thuot of the Navy, who failed twice to latch onto the satellite with a 15-foot handle. "We don't have a simulator that can put all the components together."

headline.main: MAY 10-16: From Russia With Cash; Arrests of Spies Suggest The Game Is Still On

results.snippet: The Berlin Wall has fallen and the Soviet Union is no longer, but events over the last month suggest that not all spies have come in from the cold. Some may merely be after salable secrets.   The arrest last month of five Belgians and the expulsion...
results.lead_paragraph: The Berlin Wall has fallen and the Soviet Union is no longer, but events over the last month suggest that not all spies have come in from the cold. Some may merely be after salable secrets. The arrest last month of five Belgians and the expulsion of four Russians, including two diplomats, followed the discovery of what officials here called a sophisticated ring that passed secrets of advanced technology to both the former Soviet Union and the Yeltsin Government.

headline.main: NASA Capture Bar Is Victim of Space

results.snippet: In a dramatic effort that saved their mission, three Endeavour astronauts reached up and snatched an errant satellite from space with their outstretched hands as the device that was supposed to do the job lay to the side.   After two years of...
results.lead_paragraph: In a dramatic effort that saved their mission, three Endeavour astronauts reached up and snatched an errant satellite from space with their outstretched hands as the device that was supposed to do the job lay to the side. After two years of design, development and testing, months of practice by astronauts in simulators, all at a cost of $7 million, the device finally performed as it was designed to do, securing the Intelsat-6 satellite once the astronauts grabbed it, space agency engineers said Friday. But they said the 15-foot capture bar fell victim to the limits of knowledge about how to work in the weightlessness of space.

headline.main: Canada's Leader Says Battle For Democracy Is Not Over

results.snippet: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada told graduates at Johns Hopkins University yesterday that "it is rare in history that there has been such a victory for an idea -- the idea of democracy."    "The defeat of Communism opened the door to...
results.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada told graduates at Johns Hopkins University yesterday that "it is rare in history that there has been such a victory for an idea -- the idea of democracy." "The defeat of Communism opened the door to democracy," Mr. Mulroney said. "But it also brought economic hardship to 425 million people throughout Central and Eastern Europe."

headline.main: Conquest of Outer Space: The Stamp

results.snippet: After a last-minute change in design, the United States and the Soviet Union -- uh, make that Russia -- are issuing eight stamps on Friday to celebrate their joint and separate achievements in space.   When the design was announced on Dec. 11, the...
results.lead_paragraph: After a last-minute change in design, the United States and the Soviet Union -- uh, make that Russia -- are issuing eight stamps on Friday to celebrate their joint and separate achievements in space. When the design was announced on Dec. 11, the American and Soviet astronauts shown on the upper two stamps of the blocks of four bore their nations' initials on their space suits: "USA" and "CCCP," the Cyrillic equivalent of U.S.S.R.

headline.main: 2,146 Students Graduate in Ceremonies for 122d Commencement at St. John's

results.snippet: St. John's University conferred 2,146 undergraduate degrees at three graduation ceremonies held over the weekend.    The Rev. Donald J. Harrington, president of the university, gave the keynote address at all ceremonies for the 122d commencement...
results.lead_paragraph: St. John's University conferred 2,146 undergraduate degrees at three graduation ceremonies held over the weekend. The Rev. Donald J. Harrington, president of the university, gave the keynote address at all ceremonies for the 122d commencement exercises.
